awd_titl_txt: Adaptive Fault Accommodation Based Resilient Control Techniques
awd_abstract_narration:
The research goal is to build technical foundations for designing resilient control systems which are capable of maintaining desired performance in the presence of uncertain system faults such as actuator failures, structural damage and sensor failures. The research is aimed at developing new fault detection algorithms and new adaptive and robust control methods and criteria to handle large and multiple system fault uncertainties. It will create new resilient control theory and techniques applicable to performance-critical systems such as aircraft, spacecraft, wind turbines, jet engines and intelligent robots, to enhance their safety under uncertain fault conditions. It will conduct new studies on modeling and control of systems under various fault conditions for which existing control designs are not applicable. For example, aircraft loss-of-control precursor conditions such as airframe damage, component failures, icing and turbulence effects may cause large and variant system uncertainties for which existing feedback controllers are not powerful enough. The research is expected to advance feedback control theory and technology for the need of emerging applications which require control systems to be resilient to faults, that is, have desired capabilities to accommodate uncertain and large system faults.

This research studies unique metrics of control system resilience, distinct features of resilient control problems, and key control theory requirements of performance-critical systems. It develops new control theory and design techniques to ensure desired control system resilience for multivariable nonlinear systems under uncertain multi-fault conditions. It solves new control problems such as fault detection for unstable systems, control of systems with uncertain structural characterizations, adaptive and fault-tolerant control of systems with under-actuation or non-minimum phase. These problems have the key feature that the controlled systems have fault-induced parametric, structural and functional uncertainties, difficult for most existing control schemes to deal with (to ensure both system stability and asymptotic tracking). For example, there can be uncertain failure patterns, uncertain under-actuation, uncertain system infinite zero structures, uncertain dynamic variations, caused by uncertain faults. A main goal of this research is to build a new control system design framework with specific control schemes which are capable of dealing with such unsolved system uncertainty problems, needed for resilient control systems technology. Several new feedback control methods will be developed, including: adaptive multi-layer multiple-model design (to ensure both fault handling and performance improvement abilities), adaptive multi-design integration (to deal with multiple faults), adaptive feedback-based fault detection (to have self-stabilization capacity), adaptive structural uncertainty accommodation (to deal large system structural damage), and characteristic parametrization based adaptive approximation control for non-canonical form nonlinear systems (to design an adaptable and stable controller structure). Direct control adaptation techniques will be developed for fast and smooth compensation of large and multiple fault uncertainties. New resilient control designs, for performance-guarantee fault-tolerant control, will be tested on some benchmark application system models. New concepts, theory and techniques for resilient control systems will be used for student training and knowledge dissemination.

por.por_cntn:
Actuators and sensors are important components of control systems, which are the key devices for implementing a designed feedback control signal to achieve desired system performance. Actuator and sensor failures can severely degrade control system performance and cause major safety problems. System structural damage can significantly change the system dynamics and cause large system uncertainties which can not be handled by the on-board feedback control system. It is thus desirable that the on-board control system has capacities to adaptively deal with the uncertainties caused by system faults such as actuator failures, structural damage and sensor failures. The goal of this research project was to develop new control theory and techniques for building control systems which are resilient to uncertain faults.


In this research supported by NSF grant ECCS1509704, we have solved several open control theoretical problems and built broad technical foundations for designing resilient control systems which are capable of maintaining desired performance despite the presence of uncertain actuator failures, structural damage and sensor failures. 


We studied unique metrics of control system resilience, distinct features of resilient control problems, and key control requirements of performance-critical systems. We developed new control theory and design techniques to ensure desired control system resilience for multivariable systems under uncertain multi-fault conditions. We solved new control problems such as control of systems with uncertain structural characterizations or non-parametrizable non-canonical from nonlinear dynamics, adaptive fault-tolerant control of systems with under-actuation or non-minimum phase properties. Such problems have a key feature that the controlled systems have fault-induced parametric, structural and functional uncertainties and require new adaptive control methods to deal with, to ensure desired system performance. 


We developed several new adaptive feedback control methods: adaptive multi-layer multiple-model design to ensure both fault handling and performance improvement abilities, adaptive multi-design integration to deal with multiple faults, adaptive compensation control to reject unmatched disturbances, characteristic parametrization based adaptive approximation control for non-canonical form nonlinear systems for design of adaptable and stable controller structures, partial-state feedback adaptive control for design of effective adaptive control systems with improved performance. 


We developed new adaptive and robust control algorithms and criteria to handle large and multiple system fault uncertainties. We derived new resilient control techniques applicable to performance-critical systems such as aircraft, intelligent robots, high-speed trains,multi-rotor systems, and solar-energy systems, to enhance their safety under uncertain fault conditions. For such applications, we conducted new studies on modeling and control of systems under various fault conditions, and solved open technical issues, using our developed new control methods, to deal with the uncertain faults and to ensure the desired system performance not achievable by existing control methods. 


In control systems, the occurrence of uncertain faults such as actuator failures, structural damage and sensor failures can cause large system uncertainties. Our new adaptive control methods and algorithms take into full account of such uncertainties and design specific signals in the feedback control laws to adaptively compensate such faults. In other words, our adaptive controllers are fault compensation-driven and system performance-specific. Their goals and functions are to ensure desired system performance properties including both stability and asymptotic tracking. They are designed to have the capabilities to achieve the desired resilient control system goals and functions. Such performance guarantees are crucial for aircraft flight, robot motion, train speed regulation, drone missions, and energy system operations, in the presence of uncertain system faults. Our developed adaptive control systems have the desired system resilience for performance guarantees, verified by our design, analysis, and evaluation.


Our work advanced feedback control theory and technology for the need of emerging applications which require control systems to be resilient to faults, that is, to have desired capabilities to accommodate large and multiple uncertain system faults, in addition to uncertain system parameters, nonlinearities, and disturbances, for desired performance. Our adaptive fault accommodation based resilient control techniques have been developed for general dynamic system models and are useful for a broad spectrum of practical systems, as demonstrated on some typical dynamic models of aircraft, intelligent robots, high-speed trains, multi-rotor systems, and solar-energy systems.


Our research results have been documented in our publications of 16 journal papers and 39 conference papers. Many of the results have been presented by our graduate students at conferences and by the principal investigator in 12 invited talks and keynote speeches at some universities, industries and conferences. This NSF grant has partially supported 1 MS and 4 Ph.D. students as well as the principal investigator, for their work on various topics and in related international scholarly collaboration activities. All results from this research are theoretical and have been published.
